awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CI-ADDO-NEW: Trust-Hub: Design of Trust Benchmarks, Hardware Validation Platforms and a Web-Based Dissemination Portal
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective:
The objective of Trust-Hub project is to lead a community-wide movement toward stronger assurances in
the digital hardware industry. The Trust-Hub is a means for information sharing between researchers and
practitioners to accelerate the development of defenses against hardware-level attacks. This project
proposes the development of Trust-Hub, a central web-based repository for technical papers, benchmarks,
hardware platforms, source codes, tools, and other information that accelerates hardware security research
and developments.

Intellectual Merits:
This project plans to develop benchmark circuits infected with hardware Trojans (called trust
benchmarks), create hardware platforms to validate trust benchmarks, and develop a web portal to
accelerate research and development in hardware security and trust. The project includes (i) creation of a
large set of static trust benchmarks, (ii) benchmark complexity analysis, (iii) procedures to dynamically
generate trust benchmarks with hard-to-detect Trojan instances, (iv) platforms for hardware emulation and
validation of Trojan detection methods, (vii) a web-based repository called Trust-Hub, and (viii)
comprehensive validation test suites.

Broader Impacts:
The results of this project would be of interest to fab-less semiconductor companies, US government
agencies and university researchers worldwide. Benefits to the society include trustworthy electronics for
healthcare, defense, weather forecasting, finance, transportation, and automotive applications. By
integrating the results of this project into existing courses and by offering new courses in the
undergraduate and graduate curriculum, the PIs will impart cutting-edge engineering knowledge to
students and improve their hardware design, security verification and test skills.

por.por_cntn:
It is well known that hardware security primitives such as physical unclonable function (PUF) provide great advantage over traditional software security primitives in terms of energy efficiency as well as very low latency and very high throughput. On the other hand, hardware security primitives are subject to variability of operational and environmental conditions. Software primitives are also much more flexible because they provide not just encryption mechanisms but also decryption. Our goal was to develop robust hardware security primitives that keep stated advantages while creating new types of hardware security primitive that enable not only encryption but also decryption. Our major innovation is creation of digital PUFs that are insensitive to environmental and operational conditions such as temperature  and supply voltage. We have also developed inverse PUFs that enable recovery of PUF encoded messages. Another very important contribution is development and demonstrations of reconfigurable PUFs on FPGA platforms that pass all NIST randomness tests. The new type of security primitives is also resilient against all published types of machine learning attacks. The new security primitives enable creation of variety of security and cryptographical protocols. For example, we are able to implement zero knowledge proofs that are 10 orders of magnitude faster than the current state of the art. We have also demonstrated techniques that enable simultaneous execution of two or more functionalities on the same hardware. Therefore we now enable proof that for execution of particular computation one can guarantee that it is executed at the specified platform at the specified time interval. The research effort resulted in one PhD thesis and five MS theses. In addition, we have introduced two graduate classes on hardware security primitives and protocols that were attended by more than a hundred students. We have published a book chapter, several journal and large number of conference papers at premier research venues.
